newsitem.title: THAILAND: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - March 25.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - March 25.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Thai press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Believing they have found new ammunition, police are planning to sue Attorney General Kanit na Nakhon as part of a plan to salvage their tarnished reputation in the wake of the collapse of one of the Bangkok Bank of Commerce (BBC) cases. A lawsuit against Kanit will be filed by Police Maj Gen Luan Panrosthip, who was suspended as deputy Bangkok police chief after a Finance Ministry committee ruled the police and the Bank of Thailand (BOT) were to blame for the failure to prosecute former BBC management under the banking law. (THE NATION)

- A motion seeking a corruption investigation into the planned relocation of parliament has been filed by the opposition. The motion is filed with the House Affairs Committee as the head of the purchase panel denies there has been irregularities but confirms a bribe has been offered. (BANGKOK POST)

- The resurgence of cockfighting as a national pastime has received another boost when the Interior Ministry's legal scrutiny committee agrees to redefine the restricted activity as a sport. The panel has recommended a legal change in the ministerial regulation to define cockfighting as a sport, rather than as a form of gambling, paving the way for easier public access to the chiefly rural pastime. (THE NATION)

- Pulp and paper producer Advance Agro and the Chinese government will invest 27 billion baht in a paper pulp factory to be set up at Prachin Buri province. Representatives of the Chinese government have met Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh to inform him of the deal. (BUSINESS DAY)

- The National Environment Board has approved an environmental impact assessment study of the Yadana gas pipeline project to supply gas from Burma to a power plant in Ratchaburi province. A group of residents have submitted a petition to Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh demanding the project be suspended until the assessment is completed. (BANGKOK POST) (THE NATION)

- Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh says that he will ask China to help Thailand establish a commercial navy so that operation costs for the transport of goods can be reduced. Chavalit, who will visit Beijing next week, says that apart from discussing ways to cut costs for maritime services between the two countries, he will also press for the setting up of a maritime fund. (THE NATION)
